bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 28, 1940

div1.p: Andrus forwards Lambert's letter to Truby, as well as his own sketch of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, October 28, 1940
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
10-28-40
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
Received the lay-out of yellow fever hospital and a letter
on the subject from Lambert this morning. Am sending
both to you.

The queries, in red, on the sketch are mine. The letter
is the answer to those questions.

Am also sending a layout of the entire hospital - including
the yellow fever wards - and am reasonably certain that all
parts are correct with the exception of
the warehouse,
the morgue,
the detention camp
and the yellow fever hospital.

On these four items, I am guided by Lambert's sketch and
the information contained in his letter.

You will note that I have not placed the morgue, on my draw-
ing, where he has it on his. After returning from a fur-
lough, following my recovery from yellow fever, I was on
night duty for a while and, during the day, slept in the
building I have designated as “night mens' quarters”.
You will note that this is not far from the morgue. That
is the way I remember it. Of course I can be wrong.

You will also note that I have made no effort to show quar-
ters of Captain Stark or the quarters occupied, at one time,
by Dr. and Mrs. Lazear. I do not recall these at all and
the sketch which accompanied your manuscript was sent, with
it, to Lambert.
This, I believe, finishes the job as far as I am concerned.

I hope your book is published soon as I am looking forward
with a great deal of interest to reading of other phases of
your career.
